And About These?
Again studying the hand book we find the following
listed as the "General Customs and Traditions" of the
University.
1. The main door of Gilman Hall is for use of seniors
only.
2. Hats should be removed on entering the Gilman
Memorial Room.
3. Everyone is to tip his hat to the members of the
faculty.
4. An unwritten rule given by President Goodnow
is that students may walk out of class if the professor
does not appear within five (5) minutes after the time
the class is scheduled to meet.
5. Whenever the lacrosse team plays on its home
grounds, a service flag bearing three gold stars and the
names of W. Brown Baxley, Warren B. Hunting, and
Theodore Price are to be affixed to one of the goal nets
by the captain, to remain there throughout the game.
The purpose is to keep alive the memory of a great
national service and to inspire the teams of this University to noble and efficient action. The flag is in the
keeping of the captain at all times.
6. A parade down Charles Street is held every year
on the eve of the Hopkins-St. John's football game.
7. The play of cards, checkers, chess, etc., in Levering
Hall is to be in the Lobby only. Other rooms are for
other purposes.
8. It is a Hopkins tradition to speak to every Hopkins
man you pass on the campus.
9. In the spring each class holds a banquet. The
sophomore and freshman banquets are traditionally
lively affairs. The sophs taw to capture freshmen for
their banquet and the freshmen try to reciprocate in the
same manner. Both classes attempt to held their functions
secretly. These two are proceeded by the Junior and
followed by the Senior "banquet."
How many of these are being observed? Are they
actually customs and traditions that are alive and being
followed today?

FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1937

Worthwhile Venture
The first fireside discussion sponsored by the Y.M.C.A.
at President Bowman's home proved that there is a
definite need for further sessions and that there is much
of value to be derived from them.
Of course, being the first attempt at this activity,
there were many improvements that could be made in
the program of discussion. Now the leaders, who secured valuable suggestions at the first meeting, can
more thoroughly plan future meetings and speakers.
The series should be scheduled with a definite series of
questions and faculty members to lead discussions on
them.
Student-faculty relations can be helped a great deal
by such an activity. Many problems, which may not be
treated by two individuals, are brought to light
in such informal gatherings. The relationship among
those present sometimies gives the feeling of intimacy
which allows free discussion on any subject.
These fireside discussion groups appear to be worthwhile to all who participate in them. We are looking
forward to a very successful season ahead for the rest
of the year.

The Poll Analysis
We cannot judge and interpret the results of the
recent poll fairly and adequately without taking into
consideration the varied type of motives and reasons
behind the rigid "Yes" and "No" choice.
A fairly large number of students voted "No" because
they did not feel the present bill desirable, but they
wanted an amendment or another bill permanently curtailing the Supreme Court's power. Some were personally warm supporters of President Roosevelt and his
policies; yet they feared legislation empowering future
presidents also, when they might not be in accord.
Others were clearly opposed to Roosevelt and anything
for which he stands. A few wrote "F.D.R.--dictatorship"
on their ballots, voicing the sentiments of many other
negative votes.
The student vote was very close. However to grasp
Its meaning correctly, one must appreciate the trend
towards the positive camp of the bill's support, which
Is undoubtedly taking place not only among the students but among the entire American population. We
venture to say that were this poll to be taken a few
weeks ago, the rating would have gone heavily to the
opposition.
We think that with more debate, discussion and enlightenment, more will turn to the support of the court
bill. Especially will the adherents of a court structorial
amendment realize that a temporary, constitutional
pressure is needed pending the long, difficult—if not,
impossible—task of amendment.

UNIVERSITY
I was passing the time of day in the
usual fashion in the N. L. 0. with
Marge Wege and Ed. Through Wege's
instigation, the Packing of the Court
was being soundly lauded -- but
that's not what I started to tell you
about. We were sitting there as I said,
feet on the desk, when the door was
abruptly flung against the wall. A
figure of abject terror stumbled in.
It was Uncle Humphrey. "Puh!
Puh!— "he gasped and fell into a deep
swound. We soon brought him around
and questioned him closely. "What
do you mean by coming in here yelling
'Puh! Puh!' and then passing out?
What do you?" I asked, being by this
time more aggravated than concerned
with his integrity.
The answer to our questions continued to be wild, unruly rolling of his
eyes. Finally, however, when he had
gained his breath, he got up and came
over to us. "Boys", he said, with a
demented look on his face, "There's
pixies on the campus!"
"Ha! Drunk again! Out varlet, lest
I slit thee to the gibbets!" I shouted
and would have pushed him through
the door, had not something earnest
in his look' arrested me.
"But it's true, I tell you", he
moaned. "There's a big circle of them
in the woods. I savii them as I walked
through."
"Don't be silly, there's no such
thing as a pixy, Alcibiades proves it
in his tract "Quid est Pixy?" snorted
Wege, the eternal student. This didn't
deter the small man in the least. He
drew himself up to his full height and
said, "Very well, you puerile cynics,
if you are tacitly calling me a liar,
I shall leave. But — I have seen
Pixies!" He would have gone out had
not some lesser Levering Lounger accidentally mashed him between the
door and the wall. This created a
small disturbance, but when we had
flayed in the Lounger and sunk him

neck-deep in the mud beside the Pond,
we gave aid to Uncle Humphrey's
mangled nose.
He was, as you well can imagine,
a pretty poor-looking specimen, and
on that account we gave a kindlier
ear to his sorrows. "If they were as
small as you say they were, and were
just sitting around in a circle, why
did you run away, Uncle Humphrey?"
"Well-uh-I thought I might miss
you if I didn't run," he smiled demurely.
"You just got here in time, Uncle
Humphrey" said Ed, turning the complete gentleman, "We were just going
out to hear Walter Damrosch, weren't
we, Wege?"
No one said anything
"What?
about it to me, I thought—hey what's
the idea of kicking me like that?"
"Now, Uncle Humphrey, suppose
you show us where the pixies are.
Feature story," I added to Wege,
who was engrossed in measuring columns on the dummy sheet. This
brought him to his feet, and a shining light in his eyes. "Feature story,"
he breathed incredulously, "Where?"
"Over in the woods. How's this for
a head—'Pixies Perpetrate Panic in
Park' ? "

So off we trailed through the spring
mud, soggy leaves, and bare woods
until we came to a little glen not far
from the new Club building. In the
pale, March sun, sat some fifty little
figures in a circle. All were dressed
in rough brown jerkins, green pants,
and pointed hats with feathers curling over the crown.
"There they are", whispered Uncle

(Continued from Page 2, Col. 6)
rest, seemed to be leader, so I addressed my words to him. I cleared
my throat rather nervously, being
somewhat unused to speaking before
crowds of humans, let alone pixies.
"Ho. pixies" I began, "We bring
greetings from the White Men!" The
old gentleman removed his long pipe
and said in a distinctly nasty voice,
"So what? Whatdya think we are,
Indians?" Then he added, "We're
busy with a sitdown-strike here, see?
SO what ever you want, make it snappy."
This definitely put me at a disadvantage, and while I was thinking of
something to say, Mary asked,
"Who are you boys?"
"We are the Wyman's Park Chapter
of the United and Affiliated Union
of Pixies and Trolls".
"Did you say you were on a sitdown strike?" asked Wege.
"Yeah, we want more winter, more
snow, and higher wage scales."
"Why all that?"
"For the same reason that any sane
worker wants them, but I don't suppose you'd know any thing about
that."
"I mean why do you want more
winter? I should think those caves
of yours would get cold during the
winter".
"Oh, we make it warm —hot, where
we are, "he said with a meaning look.
"What kind of work do you do with
the snow?"

"We put dirt under snow after it
falls so there's a lot of work for the
street-cleaners when it melts."
"You mean you boys put those
rocks and stuff there that we see after a snow?" I asked.
"Sure and if we don't get snow, we
can't work; no work, no pay—and
without pay we can't make the welkin ring—and that's what pixies like
best!"

The Johns Hopkins cagers smothered a valiant Loyola quintet beneath an avalanche of baskets at the
Homewood court last Tuesday. Handicapped by the absence of three
centers, Greyhounds were unable to
cope with the deadly sharp-shooting
of Herb Siegel, Carl Rasin, and Norman Melvin, and were downed 60
to 41. The Blue Jay scoring spree
set a new Maryland League record
as well as a record for the Hopkins
gymnasium.
The supremacy of the Jay quint
was never in question. Midway in
the first canto the Greyhounds
spurted and came within six points
of overtaking the Malloneemen.
The game started slowly and during the first few minutes there was
no scoring. Cross sank a twin-decker
and unleashed the irrepressible Hopkins attack. In rapid succession
Siegel, Melvin and Rasin split the
cords, and the Jays led at 13 to 2
Rasin's long range shooting during
this period was sensational. Loyola's
spurt was thwarted when Resin,
Siegel and Rubinger tallied. The half
closed with the Jays far in the lead.
Score Mounts
In the second period, Hopkins
scored almost at will. Every man on
the squad saw action and it was
Lester Rosenthal, substitute guard,
who tallied the record-breaking point.
Coach Mallonee removed his regulars
early in this half and the second
string quintet took the floor for the
remainder of the contest.
Captain Tom Carney, playing his
last collegiate game, starred for the
Evergreen aggregation, sharing high
scoring honors with Carl Resin.

And About These?
Again studying the hand book we find the following
listed as the "General Customs and Traditions" of the
University.
1. The main door of Gilman Hall is for use of seniors
only.
2. Hats should be removed on entering the Gilman
Memorial Room.
3. Everyone is to tip his hat to the members of the
faculty.
4. An unwritten rule given by President Goodnow
is that students may walk out of class if the professor
does not appear within five (5) minutes after the time
the class is scheduled to meet.
5. Whenever the lacrosse team plays on its home
grounds, a service flag bearing three gold stars and the
names of W. Brown Baxley, Warren B. Hunting, and
Theodore Price are to be affixed to one of the goal nets
by the captain, to remain there throughout the game.
The purpose is to keep alive the memory of a great
national service and to inspire the teams of this University to noble and efficient action. The flag is in the
keeping of the captain at all times.
6. A parade down Charles Street is held every year
on the eve of the Hopkins-St. John's football game.
7. The play of cards, checkers, chess, etc., in Levering
Hall is to be in the Lobby only. Other rooms are for
other purposes.
8. It is a Hopkins tradition to speak to every Hopkins
man you pass on the campus.
9. In the spring each class holds a banquet. The
sophomore and freshman banquets are traditionally
lively affairs. The sophs taw to capture freshmen for
their banquet and the freshmen try to reciprocate in the
same manner. Both classes attempt to held their functions
secretly. These two are proceeded by the Junior and
followed by the Senior "banquet."
How many of these are being observed? Are they
actually customs and traditions that are alive and being
followed today?

FRIDAY, MARCH 5, 1937

Worthwhile Venture
The first fireside discussion sponsored by the Y.M.C.A.
at President Bowman's home proved that there is a
definite need for further sessions and that there is much
of value to be derived from them.
Of course, being the first attempt at this activity,
there were many improvements that could be made in
the program of discussion. Now the leaders, who secured valuable suggestions at the first meeting, can
more thoroughly plan future meetings and speakers.
The series should be scheduled with a definite series of
questions and faculty members to lead discussions on
them.
Student-faculty relations can be helped a great deal
by such an activity. Many problems, which may not be
treated by two individuals, are brought to light
in such informal gatherings. The relationship among
those present sometimies gives the feeling of intimacy
which allows free discussion on any subject.
These fireside discussion groups appear to be worthwhile to all who participate in them. We are looking
forward to a very successful season ahead for the rest
of the year.

The Poll Analysis
We cannot judge and interpret the results of the
recent poll fairly and adequately without taking into
consideration the varied type of motives and reasons
behind the rigid "Yes" and "No" choice.
A fairly large number of students voted "No" because
they did not feel the present bill desirable, but they
wanted an amendment or another bill permanently curtailing the Supreme Court's power. Some were personally warm supporters of President Roosevelt and his
policies; yet they feared legislation empowering future
presidents also, when they might not be in accord.
Others were clearly opposed to Roosevelt and anything
for which he stands. A few wrote "F.D.R.--dictatorship"
on their ballots, voicing the sentiments of many other
negative votes.
The student vote was very close. However to grasp
Its meaning correctly, one must appreciate the trend
towards the positive camp of the bill's support, which
Is undoubtedly taking place not only among the students but among the entire American population. We
venture to say that were this poll to be taken a few
weeks ago, the rating would have gone heavily to the
opposition.
We think that with more debate, discussion and enlightenment, more will turn to the support of the court
bill. Especially will the adherents of a court structorial
amendment realize that a temporary, constitutional
pressure is needed pending the long, difficult—if not,
impossible—task of amendment.

UNIVERSITY
I was passing the time of day in the
usual fashion in the N. L. 0. with
Marge Wege and Ed. Through Wege's
instigation, the Packing of the Court
was being soundly lauded -- but
that's not what I started to tell you
about. We were sitting there as I said,
feet on the desk, when the door was
abruptly flung against the wall. A
figure of abject terror stumbled in.
It was Uncle Humphrey. "Puh!
Puh!— "he gasped and fell into a deep
swound. We soon brought him around
and questioned him closely. "What
do you mean by coming in here yelling
'Puh! Puh!' and then passing out?
What do you?" I asked, being by this
time more aggravated than concerned
with his integrity.
The answer to our questions continued to be wild, unruly rolling of his
eyes. Finally, however, when he had
gained his breath, he got up and came
over to us. "Boys", he said, with a
demented look on his face, "There's
pixies on the campus!"
"Ha! Drunk again! Out varlet, lest
I slit thee to the gibbets!" I shouted
and would have pushed him through
the door, had not something earnest
in his look' arrested me.
"But it's true, I tell you", he
moaned. "There's a big circle of them
in the woods. I savii them as I walked
through."
"Don't be silly, there's no such
thing as a pixy, Alcibiades proves it
in his tract "Quid est Pixy?" snorted
Wege, the eternal student. This didn't
deter the small man in the least. He
drew himself up to his full height and
said, "Very well, you puerile cynics,
if you are tacitly calling me a liar,
I shall leave. But — I have seen
Pixies!" He would have gone out had
not some lesser Levering Lounger accidentally mashed him between the
door and the wall. This created a
small disturbance, but when we had
flayed in the Lounger and sunk him

neck-deep in the mud beside the Pond,
we gave aid to Uncle Humphrey's
mangled nose.
He was, as you well can imagine,
a pretty poor-looking specimen, and
on that account we gave a kindlier
ear to his sorrows. "If they were as
small as you say they were, and were
just sitting around in a circle, why
did you run away, Uncle Humphrey?"
"Well-uh-I thought I might miss
you if I didn't run," he smiled demurely.
"You just got here in time, Uncle
Humphrey" said Ed, turning the complete gentleman, "We were just going
out to hear Walter Damrosch, weren't
we, Wege?"
No one said anything
"What?
about it to me, I thought—hey what's
the idea of kicking me like that?"
"Now, Uncle Humphrey, suppose
you show us where the pixies are.
Feature story," I added to Wege,
who was engrossed in measuring columns on the dummy sheet. This
brought him to his feet, and a shining light in his eyes. "Feature story,"
he breathed incredulously, "Where?"
"Over in the woods. How's this for
a head—'Pixies Perpetrate Panic in
Park' ? "

So off we trailed through the spring
mud, soggy leaves, and bare woods
until we came to a little glen not far
from the new Club building. In the
pale, March sun, sat some fifty little
figures in a circle. All were dressed
in rough brown jerkins, green pants,
and pointed hats with feathers curling over the crown.
"There they are", whispered Uncle
Humphrey, "now, my nervy nephew,
let's see you talk to them".

rest, seemed to be leader, so I addressed my words to him. I cleared
my throat rather nervously, being
somewhat unused to speaking before
crowds of humans, let alone pixies.
"Ho. pixies" I began, "We bring
greetings from the White Men!" The
old gentleman removed his long pipe
and said in a distinctly nasty voice,
"So what? Whatdya think we are,
Indians?" Then he added, "We're
busy with a sitdown-strike here, see?
SO what ever you want, make it snappy."
This definitely put me at a disadvantage, and while I was thinking of
something to say, Mary asked,
"Who are you boys?"
"We are the Wyman's Park Chapter
of the United and Affiliated Union
of Pixies and Trolls".
"Did you say you were on a sitdown strike?" asked Wege.
"Yeah, we want more winter, more
snow, and higher wage scales."
"Why all that?"
"For the same reason that any sane
worker wants them, but I don't suppose you'd know any thing about
that."
"I mean why do you want more
winter? I should think those caves
of yours would get cold during the
winter".
"Oh, we make it warm —hot, where
we are, "he said with a meaning look.
"What kind of work do you do with
the snow?"

"We put dirt under snow after it

"Sure and if we don't get snow, we
can't work; no work, no pay—and
without pay we can't make the welkin ring—and that's what pixies like
best!"

The Johns Hopkins cagers smothered a valiant Loyola quintet beneath an avalanche of baskets at the
Homewood court last Tuesday. Handicapped by the absence of three
centers, Greyhounds were unable to
cope with the deadly sharp-shooting
of Herb Siegel, Carl Rasin, and Norman Melvin, and were downed 60
to 41. The Blue Jay scoring spree
set a new Maryland League record
as well as a record for the Hopkins
gymnasium.
The supremacy of the Jay quint
was never in question. Midway in
the first canto the Greyhounds
spurted and came within six points
of overtaking the Malloneemen.
The game started slowly and during the first few minutes there was
no scoring. Cross sank a twin-decker
and unleashed the irrepressible Hopkins attack. In rapid succession
Siegel, Melvin and Rasin split the
cords, and the Jays led at 13 to 2
Rasin's long range shooting during
this period was sensational. Loyola's
spurt was thwarted when Resin,
Siegel and Rubinger tallied. The half
closed with the Jays far in the lead.
Score Mounts
In the second period, Hopkins
scored almost at will. Every man on
the squad saw action and it was
Lester Rosenthal, substitute guard,
who tallied the record-breaking point.
Coach Mallonee removed his regulars
early in this half and the second
string quintet took the floor for the
remainder of the contest.
Captain Tom Carney, playing his
last collegiate game, starred for the
Evergreen aggregation, sharing high
scoring honors with Carl Resin.
